And it repeals the “Widow’s Tax” which is what happens when a fallen servicemember’s surviving spouse – who is entitled to two gov. annuity payments – has one payment reduced dollar-for-dollar by the other. Surviving spouses depend on these payments. I’m proud to vote to fix it.

Thank you for joining me for this #FridayFocus to discuss how the appropriations process works and the importance of the process to our democratic system.

The appropriations process is an important aspect of Congress’s Constitutional power of the purse. Funding levels determined during the appropriations process are crucial to the performance of agencies and implementation of public programs.
Upon both chambers adopting an identical spending bill the bill is then sent to the President for his signature or veto.

Both chambers must pass an identical bill before it can be signed into law. If there are differences the chambers can then continue to pass amendments to each other until issues are resolved or can hold a conference of members in order to get an agreement.

Once the spending bill passes the House it is sent to the Senate for consideration. The Senate can also make changes to the bill in the form of amendments. These amendments usually become the topic of debate between the two chambers.
When a minibus like this comes to the House Floor members are given the chance to offer amendments and change funding levels of the bill before it receives a vote.

The debate this week centered on a minibus a package of 4 smaller appropriations bills. This minibus H.R. 2740 considered spending limits for Labor Health and Human Services Education Defense State and Foreign Operations and Energy and Water Development.

Following passage in the Appropriations Committee the spending bills will be brought to the House floor for a vote. The spending packages can be voted on individually all-together or in smaller groupings known as a “minibus”.
Each subcommittee will then mark up their spending proposal before sending it to the full committee for consideration.

Next each subcommittee will create a budget that allocates their total predetermined funding to the programs and agencies under their jurisdiction. This power of Congress to determine spending levels is vital for enforcing checks and balances.

Some of the letters I signed supported funding for medical research affordable housing programs community health centers community development grants law enforcement grants and gun violence prevention measures.

Congress holds the power of the purse and it is important that we craft a thoughtful budget that takes into account the needs of Americans – not just the desires of the President.

To name just a few – I’m supporting funding for medical research affordable housing programs Community  Development Block Grants community health centers law enforcement grants and gun violence prevention measures.

Deadlines are set for when these letters of support are then sent to one of the 12 subcommittees with specific jurisdiction over these programs where they are reviewed by appropriators and used to create a final budget resolution.
These letters outline recommended funding levels for programs important to our constituents.

This is where the appropriations process comes in.  Congress appropriates funding to different departments and each member can circulate and sign letters of support for programs agencies or priorities.
As I mentioned along with oversight we also play a role in the crafting of a budget resolution and the eventual bills that set funding levels for the next fiscal year.

It is important that we have the opportunity to hear from these officials because although the Executive Branch does not have the power of the purse they are in charge of overseeing the execution of the programs that Congress funds and it is important to get their insight.

As a newly appointed member of the @budgetdems it is now my responsibility to question officials on funding levels and the Committee has had three administration members come in to discuss the sharp cuts to numerous non-defense programs.
The Committee will convene regularly to receive updates on the direction of our government’s spending and how our annual budget can best reflect the priorities of our nation.
One of the Committee’s main responsibilities is to carry out oversight on budget proposals that are presented to Congress.

The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 created the Budget Committee to allow Congress to develop a self-governing group of members to analyze the President’s budget proposal and unite it with congressional plans.

It’s important to note though that these are just suggestions. The budget is what the president *wants* programs/agencies/departments to be funded at – Congress reviews the wish list and changes it to reflect *its* own priorities.

So for example if a president thinks affordable housing or the Special Olympics are good positive things that the government should get behind his budget proposal will include funding for the departments that oversee those programs.

So each year the President sends his proposed budget – what he would ideally like Congress to do – for members of Congress to review.   A budget is like a statement of principles – a president’s budget will mirror a president's values.

Everything from the Department of Defense to the National Institutes of Health fall under the Executive Branch and each year funding levels must be set. However the President does not have the power of the purse – the Constitution explicitly gives that authority to Congress.

The President’s budget is a (very large) document outlining the Administration’s policy priorities and how they ought to be funded. The document itself is very large because the Executive Branch oversees massive government agencies.
Overall the federal budget process is straightforward: in the spring the president proposes a budget Congress reviews that budget and then Congress tries to agree on a final budget resolution.

On March 11 2019 the President released his budget proposal for the next fiscal year.  This budget goes to Congress and is available to the public as a statement of the administration’s priorities.  For today’s #FridayFocus let’s look at how the budget process actually works.
